Bill Schultz ACC (Retired) William Schultz In Honored Memory of the 28 shipmates who lost their lives while fighting to save their ship. On 15 January 1969, there was an aircraft carrier flight deck fire. This one occurred aboard the aircraft carrier USS ENTERPRISE (CVAN-65) as she was sailing in the Pacific Ocean about 70 miles south west of Pearl Harbor. In all, there were 18 munition explosions or detonations. Eight holes were blown through the flight deck and deep into the ship. It took in a little over three hours to extinguish all of the fires. This incident resulted in 28 deaths and 314 injuries. There were 17 aircraft damaged and 15 destroyed. The cost of repairing the structural damage to the ship and replacing the aircraft and other equipment was over 126 million dollars. "All gave some, some gave All." Grass Valley, California 20 years

Stuart With pride I have watched my husband honor his country with 31 years of service in the U.S. Army Engineers, active duty and Reserves, graduating War College in 1987. After retirement as Colonel he continued to serve by volunteering at the local VA Hospital, putting in over 750 hours (at last count) running the shuttle. He also spends time visiting patients, sharing stories and boosting their morale. Once a month he meets with "Their Angels" to pack goodie bags for our troops stationed away from home. He has been our family's true Patriot, sharing his time and efforts, not only to keep our country free but to honor those who served and gave even more. A loving father and husband, a heartfelt patriot. I thank you for your service to our great country, and I thank you for our family and sharing 58 wonderful years. It has been an exciting and loving honor to share life with you. Point Richmond, CA 31 years

Glover Sr. BMC George Glover It wasn't until you had passed on and I matured a bit, that I realized what you had done and the contribution you had made to our nation, having served before, during, and after WWII in the Navy. I think of you more and more these days as I look at the things you left behind from your time in the Navy and I feel that I am drawn closer to you and know you better now than when I was younger. Because of you, I chose to serve in the Coast Guard. I know, shallow water sailor, puddle jumper, etc. But I now know the pride you felt have done something for your country that less than 2% of the population ever choose to do. I talk to my daughter about you, and I tell her the things I learned from you, and how you influenced my life and helped to mold me into the man that I am today. Thank you Dad, for all that you did for our great country, and all that you did for me. I could never have asked for a better father. San Diego, CA 22 years

Frank Herbert Petrone Sergeant John Peter Petrone, Ed.D Sergeant Petrone was a member of Company F, 2nd Battalion, 23rd Infantry Regiment, 2nd Infantry Division, United States Army. He was listed as Missing in Action while defending his position on Old Baldy in North Korea against a massing Chinese attack on July 17, 1952. He was presumed dead on December 31, 1953. His remains were not recovered. His name is inscribed on the Courts of the Missing at the Honolulu Memorial. Sergeant Petrone was awarded the Purple Heart, the Combat Infantryman's Badge, the Korean Service Medal, the United Nations Service Medal, the National Defense Service Medal, the Korean Presidential Unit Citation and the Republic of Korea War Service Medal. Huntington Station, New York

James O. Narey E-6, Fire Controllman 1stLt Samuel R. Houghtling To James Orville Narey: Inventor of the Precinct-Count Optical Scan Voting System (patented May 3 1977), Father of 4 ,Grandfather of 12. For your dedication to God, Family, and Country; your faithful service to our great nation during the Korean War from 1950-1952 will never be forgotten. Like so many of your brothers who paid the ultimate sacrifice, you made it possible for our nation and its allies to stand for freedom against tyranny. The people of South Korea and the United States are forever in your debt. Your actions as a Fire Controlman on a Gearing Class Destroyer, the "USS Chevalier", successfully enabled the defense of the Pusan Perimeter and the amphibious landing made by the 1st Marine Division at the port city of Inchon. For your dedication in defense of our nation during a time of war, we thank you. Fair Winds and Following Seas, and Semper Fidelis! R.I.P. Nov 1929 - June 2012. -1stLt Samuel R. Houghtling, United States Marine Corps Westminster, CA 3 years

The Indianapolis delivered the components of the Atomic Bomb and was then hit by Japanese torpedoes and was sunk in a matter of minutes. There was no time to send an SOS. The men were in the water 5 nights before miraculously being rescued. In the meantime, 880 men died, only 317 survived. Today there are only 23 still living. My dad passed away in February this year. So proud of him. Thank you to my dad and all Veterans fighting to give us the right to vote!!

Gordon Scott Aviation Chief Petty Officer Larry McFarland I dedicate my vote to WWII Navy Veteran and friend, Gordon Scott. I had the privilege and honor to accompany Gordon as his "Guardian" on a trip to Washington D.C. with the Central Valley Honor Flight. It was during this trip that I learned of Gordon's heroism and service to our country. After Navy Boot Camp, Gordon's first assignment was the USS Arizona. After his first cruise at sea, he was transferred to the Aircraft Carrier, USS Lexington. On December 6, 1941, the USS Lexington sailed out of Pearl Harbor. The Lexington had to return to Pearl Harbor on December 10 for fuel and departed again the next day. One can only imagine what it felt like to see the destruction and realize the loss of life at Pearl Harbor. Gordon served on the Lexington until May 8, 1942. On that day at 11:20 a.m., in the South China Sea, the Lexington came under torpedo and dive bomber attacks, but the Lexington continued to launch and recover aircraft. Two torpedo and two bomb hits eventually resulted in uncontrollable fires. At 17:07 p.m. the order was given to abandon ship. Gordon was among 2770 crew members who were rescued from the water by several U.S. Navy ships. Gordon went on to serve on the Aircraft Carrier USS Suwanee until the end of the war. Gordon's last assignment was to the Naval Air Station, Corpus Christi, Texas. I salute not only Gordon, but all of our Veterans and Active Duty men and women who sacrifice every day for our freedoms, including the right to vote. Kingsburg, California 1940-1946

1st Lt. Ken Ballard kia 5-30 2nd Lieutenant Joan Keith Having been a high school teacher for over 40 years, I have known many students. Yet, I have rarely been so deeply affected by any as much as the son of a former student of mine. Ken's story and his life has struck a deep chord with me. I did not know Ken as it was his mother who was my student, but from Karen's work with the Gold Star Mothers, I have come to know and admire Ken. I feel it is my loss that I did not know him. It is men like Ken who exemplify the best of America. And it is for us honor them for all they have done and for their sacrifices. From my grandfather's service in WWI to Ken's service now, men like these deserve the respect and thanks of a grateful population. They do have mine. Mountain View 9 years

Willard Clarence Markuson WT-1 Richard H Markuson My uncle Bill joined the US Navy in 1939 to serve his new country. He was killed in action on 11 December 1944 while serving aboard the USS Reid DD-369. Bill had only recently been transferred to the Reid after service on the USS Haraden (DD-585). Harden survived the war. The Reid supported air strikes against Wake Island and after patrols off Leyte, Philippine Islands, in November she steamed to Ormoc Bay, Leyte. She supported landings there in December, and escorted the damaged Lamson (DD-367) toward Leyte Gulf. Escorting reinforcements for Ormoc Bay near Surigao Straits 11 December, Reid destroyed seven Japanese planes, before she sank from repeated kamikaze crashes. Her 150 survivors were picked up by landing craft in her convoy. Uncle Bill was not one of the lucky 150. Reid received seven battle stars for World War II service. Bill received several posthumous awards for his service. Uncle Bill - I proudly display your awards on my office wall and think of you often - thank you for your service and your sacrifice. Los Angeles 5 years

Ernest Phillips Chief Master Sergeant at Travis Air Force Base, CA Thomas L. Watson We dedicate this to Ernie Phillips who on Dec. 1942 had been promoted to the rank of Staff Sergeant and was ordered to serve as an aerial left waist gunner with the aircrew of Capt. Hiram C. Skogmo with the 568th Bomb Squadron part of the 390th Bomb Group. His first plane, its nickname which was painted on the side of the fuselage by the aircrew, Six Nights in Telergma (Arabian Nights), was a B-17G flying fortress one of the most famous planes of World War II and also one of the most dangerous as Ernie was soon to learn as this plane was to make only 3 combat missions before it was shot down. Ernie and other prisoners were taken to the German Evaluation Center, Dulag Luft at Oberursel, Germany where all American aircrews would first be sent for processing. Here they would be strip searched, placed in solitary confinement and interrogated by the Germans. The interrogators would try to break down the prisoners minds to find out facts about Allied air strength, crew members and any other personal facts that could be used against other prisoners to learn military information Ernie gave them his name, rank and serial number as required by the Geneva Convention and was sent to a prisoner of war camp, possibly Stalag 17B in Krems, Austria. Ernie never spoke again about being a prisoner of war to anyone, as if it never happened. He was our hero! Vacaville, CA 28 years and 6 months

Sean Diamond Staff Sergeant Evelyn Mendez This dedication is to honor my cousin Sean who in 2009 gave the ultimate sacrifice for our freedom. During Operation Iraqi Freedom Sean was killed when an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) detonated near his vehicle in As Salam. He was on his third tour and was expected to be home the following week to spend time with his family in Ft. Lewis, WA where he was stationed. We would always look forward to their visits back to California where we would love to hang out in my parents back yard until the wee hours of the night talking, eating and laughing. He will never be forgotten and our memories of him will live on through his wife Loramay, four kids Taylor, Madison, Sean, Jr and Athena and all that loved him. I will never forget his smile and how caring he was. Every time I look at his kids I see so much of him in them and it makes my heart happy. There have been several dedications to my cousin but I am proud to be able to honor him through this dedication. Dublin, CA 9 years
